bestBHT.bht: Martha, Martha, the repetition of her name indicates a reproof that is delivered with affection. Jesus points out her inner anxiety and outward bustle, caused by her overly elaborate preparations. In her worry to make everything perfect for the Lord, she misses the opportunity to truly listen to his teachings. Jesus gently reminds her that only one dish is necessary, redirecting her attention from the multitude of tasks to the importance of his presence and teachings.

Henry Alford: The repetition of her name indicates reproof.
Thou art careful... expresses the inner anxiety.
Troubled, the outer bustle and confusion.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: Martha, Martha—emphatically redoubling upon the name."
careful and cumbered—the one word expressing the inward worrying anxiety that her preparations should be worthy of her Lord; the other, the outward bustle of those preparations.
many things—"much service" (Luke 10:40); too elaborate preparation, which so engrossed her attention that she missed her Lord's teaching.
Albert Barnes: She was improperly anxious about those things.
Marvin Vincent: Thou art anxious [μεριμνας] . See on Matthew 6:25.
Troubled [θορυβαζη] . From qorubov, tumult. Anxious denotes the inward uneasiness : troubled, the outward confusion and bustle. ===Luke 11:0
Philip Schaff: The repetition indicates reproof, but the tone is still one of affection.
The first word refers more to internal anxiety, the second to the external bustle; both together describe the habit of such a character.
The bustling about the many things in the kitchen was but a sign of the bustling about many things in her religious life.
Archibald T. Robertson: An old verb for worry and anxiety from μεριζω (μερις, part) to be divided, distracted.
Martha had both inward anxiety and outward agitation.
Jesus seems to say to Martha that only one dish was really necessary for the meal instead of the 'many' about which she was so anxious.
John Gill: Calling her by her name, and repeating it, Martha, Martha, which expresses great intimacy and friendship, and much earnestness, and, as it were, pitying her present situation and circumstances.
thou art careful and troubled about many things; intimating, that she was over anxious, and too solicitous, and more thoughtful and careful than she need be.
he reproves her for her over anxious care and solicitude, to have a nice and plentiful feast.
John Wesley: Martha, Martha — There is a peculiar spirit and tenderness in the repetition of the word: thou art careful, inwardly, and hurried, outwardly.

bhtAttempts.bht: Martha, Martha. The repeated mention of her name expresses a gentle yet firm reproof. Jesus acknowledges her inward anxiety, evident in her careful and cumbered preparations, as well as her outward bustle and confusion. Martha's many anxieties and distractions, both in the kitchen and in her religious life, cause her to miss the teachings of the Lord. Jesus lovingly reminds her that only one dish is truly necessary, redirecting her focus from the elaborate preparations to the true value of his presence and teachings.

Martha, Martha, the repetition of her name indicates a reproof that is delivered with affection. Jesus points out her inner anxiety and outward bustle, caused by her overly elaborate preparations. In her worry to make everything perfect for the Lord, she misses the opportunity to truly listen to his teachings. Jesus gently reminds her that only one dish is necessary, redirecting her attention from the multitude of tasks to the importance of his presence and teachings.

Martha, Martha, Jesus calls her by name twice, expressing both intimacy and earnestness, as well as a hint of pity for her present circumstances. He reproves her for being overly anxious and solicitous about many things, including her preparations for an elaborate feast. Her inward worrying and outward agitation reflect a character divided and distracted. Jesus reminds her that only one dish is truly necessary, gently redirecting her from excessive busyness to the value of his presence and teachings.

Martha, Martha, Jesus repeats her name with an emphatic tone, indicating both familiarity and a reproving nature. He acknowledges Martha's inward anxiety and outward bustle, arising from her excessive concern for elaborate preparations. Her preoccupation with many things, both in the kitchen and in her religious life, causes her to overlook the significance of the Lord's teachings. Jesus lovingly reminds her that only one dish is truly necessary, redirecting her focus from unnecessary busyness to the value of his presence and instruction.

Martha, Martha, Jesus repeats her name, demonstrating both intimacy and a firm reproof. He acknowledges her inward anxiety and outward bustle caused by her excessive concern for elaborate preparations. Jesus reminds her that being preoccupied with many things, both in the kitchen and in her religious life, causes her to miss the essential teachings. He lovingly guides her to recognize that only one dish is truly necessary, redirecting her focus from excessive busyness to the value of his presence and instruction.
